content.description: Good for warming up, and getting used to the gritty holds that are in this area. The topout isn't the most comfortable with all the fallen tree debris.
content.protection: Two pads is ideal, but one large pad can just be placed under the topout as the rest of the problem is low to the ground.
content.location: Stand-start matched on the same place in the juggy crack as for the Snowplow problem, but instead go rightwards up the crack feature. Finesse your body around the outcrop, get your foot way out right and top out. Try not to grab logs or sticks because they could slide which is dangerous, but more importantly that would be aid :DIt's also possible to start matching on the snowplow hold, adds in a few harder and really cool moves.

content.description: Some of the beginning moves are pretty close to the ground, so it can be difficult not to dab.Video: youtube.com/watch?v=zGwY_h5â€¦
content.protection: Two pads would probably be ideal because of the traverse. However, I got away with one pad beneath the traverse/topout, as the rest of the problem is fairly low to the ground.
content.location: Sit-start on the two crimps highlighted in the photo. Get up to the obvious slot near the top of the wall, then traverse right to the same topout as the Snowplow.A lower sit start is possible, it adds in ~2 moves that are significantly harder.

content.description: Strange but awesome moves up the flake feature on the main face, probably the best line here. Good choice in footholds can make this easier than meets the eye.Video: youtu.be/HtGwcGLZzfA
content.protection: One Metolius Magnum was enough for me, but two pads wouldn't hurt.
content.location: Stand start matched on the juggy crack around waist height, and use the crimp on your left to get to the snowplow. Use the sidepull on the flake to get to the good ledge, then top out.

content.description: Probably the toughest line in the area.
content.location: Same start and first move as the snowplow problem, but instead move to the horizontal crack for some crimps.

content.description: This boulder is named after the prominent, juggy crest on the front of the face that resembles the snowplow on the front of a train.Most of the wall is gritty, but some crimps are very smooth. Very interesting movement on these features.
